Title: Anole: a case for energy-aware mobile application design
Authors: Chen, Hui; Luo, Bing; Shi, Weisong
Venue: 2012 41st International Conference on Parallel Processing Workshops
Notes: Makes the implementation of a framework to make energy-management apis available to application and OS developers. However, they mainly focus on one possible implementation of such framework, rather than on the use energy-management frameworks from the perspective of software developers.

Title: Refactoring android java code for on-demand computation offloading
Authors: Zhang, Ying; Huang, Gang; Liu, Xuanzhe; Zhang, Wei; Mei, Hong; Yang, Shunxiang
Venue: ACM Sigplan Notices
Notes: Paper proposes a program, DPartner, that automatically refactors an application to offload available classes to the cloud. Although technical implementation of DPartner are outside the scope of this research, the main algorithm to identify movable classes is of interest to software developers writing application level software. As such, it will be included in the snowballing.

Title: Studying energy trade offs in offloading computation/compilation in java-enabled mobile devices
Authors: Chen, Guangyu; Kang, B.-T.; Kandemir, Mahmut; Vijaykrishnan, Narayanan; Irwin, Mary Jane; Chandramouli, Rajarathnam
Venue: IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems
Notes: Paper describes the use of a proxy to stand in for class interfaces that chooses at run time whether an application should offload certain parts of its code to a remote server or execute locally with some optimizations.

Title: Manageable granularity in mobile application code offloading for energy savings
Authors: Yang, Sirui
Venue: 2012 IEEE International Conference on Green Computing and Communications
Notes: Paper implements a semi-automatic method offloading technique named MACO where application code is partitioned into computational and UI codes.

Title: Estimating mobile application energy consumption using program analysis
Authors: Hao, Shuai; Li, Ding; Halfond, William GJ; Govindan, Ramesh
Venue: 2013 35th international conference on software engineering (ICSE)
Notes: Paper proposes a new energy consumption measurement approach that is both lightweight in terms of its developer requirements and provides fine-grained estimates of energy consumption at the code level.KSR7NJ2X. Paper proposes a technique that measures energy consumption of applications written for Android mobile devices and provides accurate estimates with a 10% difference from ground truth of their energy consumption. However, the paper focuses on the implementation of the technique itself instead of focusing on application software energy efficiency tactics.

Title: Initial explorations on design pattern energy usage
Authors: Sahin, Cagri; Cayci, Furkan; Gutierrez, Irene Lizeth Manotas; Clause, James; Kiamilev, Fouad; Pollock, Lori; Winbladh, Kristina
Venue: 2012 First International Workshop on Green and Sustainable Software (GREENS)
Notes: Paper proposes a novel way of measuring software consumption by analyzing different software components. Paper also describes design patterns and their energy consumption. They find that some patterns increase energy efficiency, while others significantly decrease efficiency.

Title: Extending software architecture views with an energy consumption perspective
Authors: Jagroep, Erik; van der Werf, Jan Martijn; Brinkkemper, Sjaak; Blom, Leen; van Vliet, Rob
Venue: Computing
Notes: Paper explicitly proposes green software tactics at the application level.

Title: Green software architectures: A market-based approach
Authors: Rangaraj, Govindaraj; Bahsoon, Rami
Venue: The Second International Workshop on Software Research and Climate Change (WSRCC)
Notes: Paper proposes a dynamic self-management software architecture framework for power based on economic theory. However, it is not immediately clear at which level this software tactic sits. After further examination, it seems that this application would sit at the DevOps level, qualifying under the application software level.

Title: Model-based energy efficiency analysis of software architectures
Authors: Stier, Christian; Koziolek, Anne; Groenda, Henning; Reussner, Ralf
Venue: European conference on software architecture
Notes: Paper proposes a modeling approach at design time that can estimate to high accuracy the energy efficiency of a software architecture.

Title: Differences of energetic consumption between Java and JNI Android apps
Authors: Ramírez, Ricardo Isidro; Rubio, Erika Hernández; Viveros, Amilcar Meneses; Hernández, Irene Monserrat Torres
Venue: 2014 International Symposium on Integrated Circuits (ISIC)
Notes: Paper compares the an application using JNI and Java vs only Java. The paper finds that applications built with JNI perform better and have lower energy consumption. As such, one could extract a tactic to use JNI alongside Java to increase the energy efficiency of applications.

Title: Energy efficiency across programming languages: how do energy, time, and memory relate?
Authors: Pereira, Rui; Couto, Marco; Ribeiro, Francisco; Rua, Rui; Cunha, Jácome; Fernandes, João Paulo; Saraiva, João
Venue: Proceedings of the 10th ACM SIGPLAN International Conference on Software Language Engineering
Notes: Paper analyses programing languages and propose which language to use in order to achieve different energy, time, and memory objectives.

Title: Program energy efficiency: The impact of language, compiler and implementation choices
Authors: Abdulsalam, Sarah; Lakomski, Donna; Gu, Qijun; Jin, Tongdan; Zong, Ziliang
Venue: International Green Computing Conference
Notes: Paper analyses the the impact of languages (C/C++/Java/Python), compiler optimization (GNU C/C++ compiler with O1, O2, and O3 flags) and implementation choices (e.g. using malloc instead of new to create dynamic arrays and using vector vs. array for Quicksort) on the energy-efficiency of three programs.

Title: Energy-efficient code by refactoring
Authors: Gottschalk, Marion; Jelschen, Jan; Winter, Andreas
Venue: Softwaretechnik-Trends: Vol. 33, No. 2
Notes: Paper proposes software energy efficiency tactics for mobile applications.

Title: Greenadvisor: A tool for analyzing the impact of software evolution on energy consumption
Authors: Aggarwal, Karan; Hindle, Abram; Stroulia, Eleni
Venue: 2015 IEEE international conference on software maintenance and evolution (ICSME)
Notes: Paper proposes the measuring tool Green Advisor and conducts a case study where the energy efficiency of commits using Green Advisor is compared against those not using Green Advisor.

Title: Greenminer: A hardware based mining software repositories software energy consumption framework
Authors: Hindle, Abram; Wilson, Alex; Rasmussen, Kent; Barlow, E. Jed; Campbell, Joshua Charles; Romansky, Stephen
Venue: Proceedings of the 11th working conference on mining software repositories
Notes: Paper proposes Green Miner, a green metrics as a service that allows developers to test the energy efficiency of their Android applications.

Title: Mining energy-greedy api usage patterns in android apps: an empirical study
Authors: Linares-Vásquez, Mario; Bavota, Gabriele; Bernal-Cárdenas, Carlos; Oliveto, Rocco; Di Penta, Massimiliano; Poshyvanyk, Denys
Venue: Proceedings of the 11th working conference on mining software repositories
Notes: Paper analyzes Android API’s and proposes tactics at the application level to minimize energy consumption.HFGU26NT. Paper “quantitatively and qualitatively investigating energy-greedy API calls and patterns identified from 55 free Android apps.” (Linares-Vásquez et al., 2014, p. 9)

Title: Refactoring for energy efficiency: A reflection on the state of the art
Authors: Pinto, Gustavo; Soares-Neto, Francisco; Castor, Fernando
Venue: 2015 IEEE/ACM 4th International Workshop on Green and Sustainable Software
Notes: Paper reviews code refactoring techniques for energy efficiency.

Title: Greening an existing software system using the GPU
Authors: Scanniello, Giuseppe; Erra, Ugo; Caggianese, Giuseppe; Gravino, Carmine
Venue: Software-Practice & Experience
Notes: Paper proposes to migrate energy intensive application software to the GPU whenever possible as well as giving some pros and cons of the migration.

Title: Impacts of software and its engineering on the carbon footprint of ICT
Authors: Kern, Eva; Dick, Markus; Naumann, Stefan; Hiller, Tim
Venue: Environmental Impact Assessment Review
Notes: Paper proposes to measure software’s energy consumption during the CI cycle to provide immediate feedback to developers on their software consumption.

Title: Greenbundle: an empirical study on the energy impact of bundled processing
Authors: Chowdhury, Shaiful Alam; Hindle, Abram; Kazman, Rick; Shuto, Takumi; Matsui, Ken; Kamei, Yasutaka
Venue: 2019 IEEE/ACM 41st International Conference on Software Engineering (ICSE)
Notes: Paper proposes refactoring from the MVC architectural pattern to a bundled model-view-presenter architectural pattern.

Title: Catalog of energy patterns for mobile applications
Authors: Cruz, Luis; Abreu, Rui
Venue: Empirical Software Engineering
Notes: Paper proposes 22 energy efficient design patterns for mobile applications collected from github commits and pull requests.

Title: Measuring application software energy efficiency
Authors: Capra, Eugenio; Francalanci, Chiara; Slaughter, Sandra A.
Venue: IT Professional
Notes: Paper proposes to refactor methods to use memory space instead of CPU power when performing computational intensive processes.

Title: Using the Greenup, Powerup, and Speedup metrics to evaluate software energy efficiency
Authors: Abdulsalam, Sarah; Zong, Ziliang; Gu, Qijun; Qiu, Meikang
Venue: 2015 Sixth International Green and Sustainable Computing Conference (IGSC)
Notes: Paper proposes a new method of measuring a system’s energy consumption by introducing the Greenup, Powerup, and Speedup metrics. These metrics help evaluate different software implementations and compare which ones give better performance. The paper also proposes 8 types of categorizations for software optimizations and rank them on their ability to improve energy efficiency.

Title: Green IT–Available data and guidelines for reducing energy consumption in IT systems
Authors: Ardito, Luca; Morisio, Maurizio
Venue: Sustainable Computing: Informatics and Systems
Notes: Paper proposes a taxonomy for energy efficient tactics, and provides several tactics at the application layer. Paper also defines application, hardware, and OS level.

Title: Understanding green software development: A conceptual framework
Authors: Ardito, Luca; Procaccianti, Giuseppe; Torchiano, Marco; Vetro, Antonio
Venue: IT Professional
Notes: Paper proposes a framework to implement energy efficiency tactics and measure the energy savings from the resulting modifications.

Title: Green web services: Modeling and estimating power consumption of web services
Authors: Bartalos, Peter; Blake, M. Brian
Venue: 2012 IEEE 19th International Conference on Web Services
Notes: Paper proposes a dynamic energy consumption measuring framework that correlates software architecture characteristics to the energy efficiency of a distributed system.

Title: Is software “green”? Application development environments and energy efficiency in open source applications
Authors: Capra, Eugenio; Francalanci, Chiara; Slaughter, Sandra A.
Venue: Information and Software Technology
Notes: Paper proposes a new measuring method to measure energy consumption of software for high level software applications. The paper also explores the relation between development environments and energy efficiency.

Title: An Aspect Oriented Model for Software Energy Efficiency in Decentralised Servers.
Authors: Chinenyeze, Samuel; Liu, Xiaodong; Al-Dubai, Ahmed Yassin
Venue: ICT4S
Notes: Paper proposes to use an aspect-oriented programming model to increase the energy efficiency of a server-client architecture.

Title: Green software engineering: the curse of methodology
Authors: Hindle, Abram
Venue: 2016 IEEE 23rd International Conference on Software Analysis, Evolution, and Reengineering (SANER)
Notes: Paper performs systematic literature review of tactics to improve on energy efficiency.

Title: Software optimization for performance, energy, and thermal distribution: Initial case studies
Authors: Khan, Md Ashfaquzzaman; Hankendi, Can; Coskun, Ayse Kivilcim; Herbordt, Martin C.
Venue: 2011 International Green Computing Conference and Workshops
Notes: Paper proposes an energy consumption measuring framework and proposes to use parallelization to increase the energy efficiency of a compression application.

Title: Monitoring energy hotspots in software
Authors: Noureddine, Adel; Rouvoy, Romain; Seinturier, Lionel
Venue: Automated Software Engineering
Notes: Paper proposes a new energy consumption framework measuring to measure energy consumption hotspots.

Title: Empirical evaluation of two best practices for energy-efficient software development
Authors: Procaccianti, Giuseppe; Fernández, Héctor; Lago, Patricia
Venue: Journal of Systems and Software
Notes: Paper proposes analyzes the impact of best practices on energy consumption.

Title: Towards power reduction through improved software design
Authors: Sahin, Cagri; Cayci, Furkan; Clause, James; Kiamilev, Fouad; Pollock, Lori; Winbladh, Kristina
Venue: 2012 IEEE Energytech
Notes: Paper proposes a tactic to reduce the energy consumption of software by analyzing the energy consumption of software, and then mapping it to the high-level software engineering concepts.

Title: The software perspective for energy-efficient mobile applications development
Authors: Siebra, Clauirton; Costa, Paulo; Miranda, Regina; Silva, Fabio QB; Santos, Andre
Venue: Proceedings of the 10th International Conference on Advances in Mobile Computing & Multimedia
Notes: Paper proposes a technique to measure the energy consumption of certain parts of software, re-implement those parts in a more energy conscious manner, and retest the code to find energy efficiency gains.

Title: Impact of developer choices on energy consumption of software on servers
Authors: Singh, Jasmeet; Naik, Kshirasagar; Mahinthan, Veluppillai
Venue: Procedia Computer Science
Notes: Paper analyzes the energy consumption of different APIs and demonstrates that the choice of APIs can significantly improve an application’s energy efficiency.

Title: Evaluation of Software Product Quality Attributes and Environmental Attributes using ANP Decision Framework.
Authors: Koçak, Sedef Akinli; Alptekin, Gülfem Isiklar; Bener, Ayse
Venue: RE4SuSy@ RE
Notes: Paper proposes to weight the priority weights between software quality criteria and environmental characteristics.

Title: Seeds: A software engineer's energy-optimization decision support framework
Authors: Manotas, Irene; Pollock, Lori; Clause, James
Venue: Proceedings of the 36th International Conference on Software Engineering
Notes: Paper proposes an automated support for systematically optimizing the energy usage of applications by making code-level changes.

Title: Performance events based full system estimation on application power consumption
Authors: Yang, Shu; Luan, Zhongzhi; Li, Binyang; Zhang, Ge; Huang, Tianming; Qian, Depei
Venue: 2016 IEEE 18th International Conference on High Performance Computing and Communications; IEEE 14th International Conference on Smart City; IEEE 2nd International Conference on Data Science and Systems (HPCC/SmartCity/DSS)
Notes: Paper proposes technique to to estimate application power consumption in the full system with performance events.

Title: Early analysis of resource consumption patterns in mobile applications
Authors: Berrocal, Javier; Garcia-Alonso, Jose; Vicente-Chicote, Cristina; Hernández, Juan; Mikkonen, Tommi; Canal, Carlos; Murillo, Juan M.
Venue: Pervasive and Mobile Computing
Notes: Paper proposes a conceptual framework which analyzes the consumption pattern of applications in their early development phases. It also uses the framework to analyze two different software architectures for mobile applications.

Title: Energy consumption and efficiency in mobile applications: A user feedback study
Authors: Wilke, Claas; Richly, Sebastian; Götz, Sebastian; Piechnick, Christian; Aßmann, Uwe
Venue: 2013 IEEE International Conference on Green Computing and Communications and IEEE Internet of Things and IEEE Cyber, Physical and Social Computing
Notes: Paper conducts a study on the number of users that complain about mobile applications’ energy consumption, and the reasons why energy consumption might be excessive. It also presents some solutions on how developers can deal with these energy inefficiencies.

Title: Energy-efficient multisite offloading policy using Markov decision process for mobile cloud computing
Authors: Terefe, Mati B.; Lee, Heezin; Heo, Nojung; Fox, Geoffrey C.; Oh, Sangyoon
Venue: Pervasive and Mobile Computing
Notes: Paper proposes an algorithm that analyzes an application’s data and computation intensive modules, and offloads them to the server in a cloud provider that provides the most energy savings.

Title: Share sens: An approach to optimizing energy consumption of continuous mobile sensing workloads
Authors: Moamen, Ahmed Abdel; Jamali, Nadeem
Venue: 2015 IEEE International Conference on Mobile Services
Notes: Paper proposes an API which applications can use to access a device’s sensors that saves energy.

Title: Toward using software metrics as indicator to measure power consumption of mobile application: A case study
Authors: Keong, Ching Kin; Wei, Koh Tieng; Ghani, Abdul Azim Abd; Sharif, Khaironi Yatim
Venue: 2015 9th Malaysian Software Engineering Conference (MySEC)
Notes: Paper finds correlation between software metrics and energy efficiency in mobile applications.

Title: Accurate online power estimation and automatic battery behavior based power model generation for smartphones
Authors: Zhang, Lide; Tiwana, Birjodh; Qian, Zhiyun; Wang, Zhaoguang; Dick, Robert P.; Mao, Zhuoqing Morley; Yang, Lei
Venue: Proceedings of the eighth IEEE/ACM/IFIP international conference on Hardware/software codesign and system synthesis
Notes: Paper proposes power tutor and power booter, two frameworks that aid mobile application developers estimating the power consumption of their software.

Title: ${$AppScope$}$: Application Energy Metering Framework for Android Smartphone Using Kernel Activity Monitoring
Authors: Yoon, Chanmin; Kim, Dongwon; Jung, Wonwoo; Kang, Chulkoo; Cha, Hojung
Venue: 2012 USENIX Annual Technical Conference (USENIX ATC 12)
Notes: Paper proposes an application measuring software that monitors an application’s hardware usage at the kernel level and estimates power consumption.

Title: Knowledge for a longer life: development impetus for energy-efficient smartphone applications
Authors: Hans, Ronny; Burgstahler, Daniel; Mueller, Alexander; Zahn, Manuel; Stingl, Dominik
Venue: 2015 IEEE International Conference on Mobile Services
Notes: Paper does an SLR on techniques application developers can use to reduce energy consumption.

Title: Mobile device power models for energy efficient dynamic offloading at runtime
Authors: Ali, Farhan Azmat; Simoens, Pieter; Verbelen, Tim; Demeester, Piet; Dhoedt, Bart
Venue: Journal of Systems and Software
Notes: Paper proposes a energy estimation framework that can be used to estimate an application’s energy consumption on the cloud, on the device or both. It then uses the estimation to perform decisions at application runtime.

Title: Phone2Cloud: Exploiting computation offloading for energy saving on smartphones in mobile cloud computing
Authors: Xia, Feng; Ding, Fangwei; Li, Jie; Kong, Xiangjie; Yang, Laurence T.; Ma, Jianhua
Venue: Information Systems Frontiers
Notes: Paper proposes a framework that measures an application’s energy usage, and the user’s time tolerance to offload computation to the cloud.

Title: Time-and-energy-aware computation offloading in handheld devices to coprocessors and clouds
Authors: Lin, Ying-Dar; Chu, Edward T.-H.; Lai, Yuan-Cheng; Huang, Ting-Jun
Venue: IEEE Systems Journal
Notes: Paper proposes a decision framework that can be utilized by application developers to offload CPU-intensive computations to the cloud or to the GPU.

Title: Assessment of rest and websocket in regards to their energy consumption for mobile applications
Authors: Herwig, Volker; Fischer, René; Braun, Peter
Venue: 2015 IEEE 8th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
Notes: Paper analyzes the energy consumption of REST vs WebSocket technologies in mobile applications.

Title: Sustainable approaches and good practices in green software engineering
Authors: Agarwal, Shalabh; Nath, Asoke; Chowdhury, Dipayan
Venue: International Journal of Research and Reviews in Computer Science
Notes: Paper proposes tactics that can be used at the development stage of application software.

Title: Evaluating the impact of code smell refactoring on the energy consumption of android applications
Authors: Anwar, Hina; Pfahl, Dietmar; Srirama, Satish N.
Venue: 2019 45th Euromicro Conference on Software Engineering and Advanced Applications (SEAA)
Notes: Paper proposes refactoring tools that improve the energy efficiency of application software.

Title: Data-oriented characterization of application-level energy optimization
Authors: Liu, Kenan; Pinto, Gustavo; Liu, Yu David
Venue: International Conference on Fundamental Approaches to Software Engineering
Notes: Paper proposes a library to measure a specific code’s energy consumption in the Java language.

Title: Earmo: An energy-aware refactoring approach for mobile apps
Authors: Morales, Rodrigo; Saborido, Rubén; Khomh, Foutse; Chicano, Francisco; Antoniol, Giuliano
Venue: IEEE Transactions on Software Engineering
Notes: Paper proposes a framework that gives energy oriented refactoring recommendations for mobile applications.

Title: Green software: Refactoring approach
Authors: Sehgal, Rajni; Mehrotra, Deepti; Nagpal, Renuka; Sharma, Ramanuj
Venue: Journal of King Saud University-Computer and Information Sciences
Notes: Paper proposes to use refactoring techniques to reduce energy consumption in Java applications.

Title: Code Smell Refactoring for Energy Optimization of Android Apps
Authors: Sehgal, Rajni; Mehrotra, Deepti; Nagpal, Renuka; Choudhury, Tanupriya
Venue: Innovations in Cyber Physical Systems
Notes: Paper investigates the impact of code smells and their refactoring in energy consumption. The paper proposes to refactor the following smells in order to reduce energy consumption: god class, feature envy, and long method.

Title: Inheritance versus delegation: Which is more energy efficient?
Authors: Connolly Bree, Déaglán; Cinnéide, Mel Ó
Venue: Proceedings of the IEEE/ACM 42nd International Conference on Software Engineering Workshops
Notes: Paper investigates the use of inheritance vs delegation and finds that inheritance is 77% more computationally efficient and 4% more energy efficient.

Title: On the impact of code smells on the energy consumption of mobile applications
Authors: Palomba, Fabio; Di Nucci, Dario; Panichella, Annibale; Zaidman, Andy; De Lucia, Andrea
Venue: Information and Software Technology
Notes: Paper investigates the energy consumption of four code smells, and finds that they use 87 times more energy than other code smells. The paper also proposes refactoring techniques. “The results of the study highlight that methods affected by four code smell types, i.e., Internal Setter, Leaking Thread, Member Ignoring Method, and Slow Loop, consume up to 87 times more than methods affected by other code smells. Moreover, we found that refactoring these code smells reduces energy consumption in all of the situations.” (Palomba et al., 2019, p. 1)

Title: A process for analysing the energy efficiency of software
Authors: Mancebo, Javier; García, Félix; Calero, Coral
Venue: Information and Software Technology
Notes: Paper proposes a framework to analyze the energy consumption of software.

Title: Modeling, profiling, and debugging the energy consumption of mobile devices
Authors: Hoque, Mohammad Ashraful; Siekkinen, Matti; Khan, Kashif Nizam; Xiao, Yu; Tarkoma, Sasu
Venue: ACM Computing Surveys (CSUR)
Notes: Paper compares energy consumption measuring tools. Although most of these tools are not all at the application level, we can focus on those that are application level.

Title: Investigating the correlation between performance scores and energy consumption of mobile web apps
Authors: Chan-Jong-Chu, Kwame; Islam, Tanjina; Exposito, Miguel Morales; Sheombar, Sanjay; Valladares, Christian; Philippot, Olivier; Grua, Eoin Martino; Malavolta, Ivano
Venue: Proceedings of the evaluation and assessment in software engineering
Notes: Paper proposes for developers to increase their web app’s lighthouse performance score to reduce energy consumption.

Title: Green mining: a methodology of relating software change and configuration to power consumption
Authors: Hindle, Abram
Venue: Empirical Software Engineering
Notes: Paper proposes a methodology to relate software changes to energy consumption by “measuring the power consumption of tests of multiple versions of a software system by combining power measurement and mining software repositories methodologies.” (Hindle, 2015, p. 407).

Title: The power of system call traces: predicting the software energy consumption impact of changes.
Authors: Aggarwal, Karan; Zhang, Chenlei; Campbell, Joshua Charles; Hindle, Abram; Stroulia, Eleni
Venue: CASCON
Notes: Paper proposes a novel technique of measuring energy consumption by using measuring the changes in system calls between software versions.

Title: Towards a green ranking for programming languages
Authors: Couto, Marco; Pereira, Rui; Ribeiro, Francisco; Rua, Rui; Saraiva, João
Venue: Proceedings of the 21st Brazilian Symposium on Programming Languages
Notes: Paper measures the energy consumption of different programming languages and proposes to use statically compiled languages to improve energy efficiency.

Title: A green software development life cycle for cloud computing
Authors: Chauhan, Nitin Singh; Saxena, Ashutosh
Venue: IT Professional
Notes: Paper proposes several techniques for cloud users to increase the energy efficiency of their applications.

Title: Energy efficient software development life cycle-An approach towards smart computing
Authors: Sharma, Sunil Kumar; Gupta, P. K.; Malekian, Reza
Venue: 2015 IEEE International Conference on Computer Graphics, Vision and Information Security (CGVIS)
Notes: Paper proposes a green software development lifecycle process that ensures optimal energy consumption of the system being developed.

Title: A programming environment with runtime energy characterization for energy-aware applications
Authors: Xian, Changjiu; Lu, Yung-Hsiang; Li, Zhiyuan
Venue: Proceedings of the 2007 international symposium on Low power electronics and design (ISLPED'07)
Notes: Paper proposes an API that allows application developers to create energy-aware applications.

Title: Detecting energy bugs and hotspots in mobile apps
Authors: Banerjee, Abhijeet; Chong, Lee Kee; Chattopadhyay, Sudipta; Roychoudhury, Abhik
Venue: Proceedings of the 22nd ACM SIGSOFT International Symposium on Foundations of Software Engineering
Notes: Paper proposes a test framework that detects energy hotspots/bugs in an application.

Title: Deep parameter optimisation on android smartphones for energy minimisation: a tale of woe and a proof-of-concept
Authors: Bokhari, Mahmoud A.; Bruce, Bobby R.; Alexander, Brad; Wagner, Markus
Venue: Proceedings of the Genetic and Evolutionary Computation Conference Companion
Notes: Paper proposes a deep parameter optimization to improve on android applications.

Title: Search-based energy optimization of some ubiquitous algorithms
Authors: Brownlee, Alexander Edward Ian; Burles, Nathan; Swan, Jerry
Venue: IEEE Transactions on Emerging Topics in Computational Intelligence
Notes: Paper proposes to measure JVM application’s compiled bytecode to find the energy efficiency of an application. It then proposes genetic based algorithms to improve on the code.

Title: Reducing energy consumption using genetic improvement
Authors: Bruce, Bobby R.; Petke, Justyna; Harman, Mark
Venue: Proceedings of the 2015 Annual Conference on Genetic and Evolutionary Computation
Notes: Paper proposes a genetic improvement technique that optimizes the energy efficiency of applications.

Title: Choosing the" Best" Sorting Algorithm for Optimal Energy Consumption.
Authors: Bunse, Christian; Höpfner, Hagen; Roychoudhury, Suman; Mansour, Essam
Venue: ICSOFT (2)
Notes: Paper proposes to dynamically replace sorting algorithms based on the system’s energy consumption to find the most energy efficient sorting algorithm.

Title: Object-oriented genetic improvement for improved energy consumption in Google Guava
Authors: Burles, Nathan; Bowles, Edward; Brownlee, Alexander EI; Kocsis, Zoltan A.; Swan, Jerry; Veerapen, Nadarajen
Venue: International Symposium on Search Based Software Engineering
Notes: Paper introduces “‘Object-Oriented Genetic Improvement’, a technique by which non-functional properties such as time or energy consumption may be optimised by substituting suitable alternative subclasses to constructor invocations” (Burles et al., 2015, p. 6)

Title: Characterizing the performance and energy efficiency of lock-free data structures
Authors: Hunt, Nicholas; Sandhu, Paramjit Singh; Ceze, Luis
Venue: 2011 15th Workshop on Interaction between Compilers and Computer Architectures
Notes: Paper proposes the use of lock free data-structures to increase the efficiency of multi-threaded applications.

Title: Optimizing energy consumption of guis in android apps: A multi-objective approach
Authors: Linares-Vásquez, Mario; Bavota, Gabriele; Cárdenas, Carlos Eduardo Bernal; Oliveto, Rocco; Di Penta, Massimiliano; Poshyvanyk, Denys
Venue: Proceedings of the 2015 10th Joint Meeting on Foundations of Software Engineering
Notes: Paper proposes to use optimized color schemes in GUIs to reduce the energy consumption of mobile applications.

Title: Jolinar: analysing the energy footprint of software applications
Authors: Noureddine, Adel; Islam, Syed; Bashroush, Rabih
Venue: Proceedings of the 25th International Symposium on Software Testing and Analysis
Notes: Paper proposes Jolinar, an energy consumption measuring tool for applications directed at software developers and end users.

Title: Ape: An annotation language and middleware for energy-efficient mobile application development
Authors: Nikzad, Nima; Chipara, Octav; Griswold, William G.
Venue: Proceedings of the 36th International Conference on Software Engineering
Notes: Paper “present APE, an annotation language and middleware service that eases the development of energy-efficient Android applications.” (Nikzad et al., 2014, p. 515)

Title: A preliminary study of the impact of software engineering on greenit
Authors: Noureddine, Adel; Bourdon, Aurelien; Rouvoy, Romain; Seinturier, Lionel
Venue: 2012 First International Workshop on Green and Sustainable Software (GREENS)
Notes: Paper “present the POWERAPI architecture. It allows gathering and calculating the power consumption of processes and applications” (Noureddine et al., 2012, p. 8)

Title: Mining questions about software energy consumption
Authors: Pinto, Gustavo; Castor, Fernando; Liu, Yu David
Venue: Proceedings of the 11th Working Conference on Mining Software Repositories
Notes: Paper mines stack overflow for questions on energy consumption, and then provides techniques to address them.

Title: Understanding energy behaviors of thread management constructs
Authors: Pinto, Gustavo; Castor, Fernando; Liu, Yu David
Venue: Proceedings of the 2014 ACM International Conference on Object Oriented Programming Systems Languages & Applications
Notes: Paper “presents a study on how concurrent programming practices may have impact on energy consumption.” (Pinto et al., 2014, p. 359)

Title: How to measure energy-efficiency of software: Metrics and measurement results
Authors: Johann, Timo; Dick, Markus; Naumann, Stefan; Kern, Eva
Venue: 2012 First International Workshop on Green and Sustainable Software (GREENS)
Notes: Paper proposes a technique to measure “energy consumption of specific parts of software which can be measured with a white box method and programmers are able to find resource intensive code, which is an advantage compared to black box methods” (Johann et al., 2012, p. 54)

Title: A review of energy measurement approaches
Authors: Noureddine, Adel; Rouvoy, Romain; Seinturier, Lionel
Venue: ACM SIGOPS Operating Systems Review
Notes: Paper reviews methods of measuring energy consumption during application runtime such as PowerScope and Jalen.

Title: Fine-grained power management using process-level profiling
Authors: Chen, Hui; Li, Youhuizi; Shi, Weisong
Venue: Sustainable Computing: Informatics and Systems
Notes: Paper proposes “the pTopW on Windows platform. This tool supplies two convenient user interfaces, which are APIs and performance counter, for poweraware applications” (Chen et al., 2012, p. 2) This paper is an extension of the previous pTop paper in that this measuring framework works for Windows.

Title: Unit testing of energy consumption of software libraries
Authors: Noureddine, Adel; Rouvoy, Romain; Seinturier, Lionel
Venue: Proceedings of the 29th Annual ACM Symposium on Applied Computing
Notes: Paper proposes “JalenUnit, a software framework that infers the energy consumption model of software libraries from execution traces.” (Noureddine et al., 2014, p. 1200)

Title: ptop: A process-level power profiling tool
Authors: Do, Thanh; Rawshdeh, Suhib; Shi, Weisong
Notes: Paper proposes “the design and implementation of pTop, a simple and efficient process-level power profiling tool.” (Do et al., 2009, p. 1)

Title: Saving Energy on Mobile Devices by Refactoring.
Authors: Gottschalk, Marion; Jelschen, Jan; Winter, Andreas
Venue: EnviroInfo
Notes: “This paper shows an approach to save energy on the application level on mobile devices. This approach includes the definition, detection, and restructuring of energy-inefficient code parts.” (Gottschalk et al., 2014, p. 1)

Title: Towards applying reengineering services to energy-efficient applications
Authors: Jelschen, Jan; Gottschalk, Marion; Josefiok, Mirco; Pitu, Cosmin; Winter, Andreas
Venue: 2012 16th European Conference on Software Maintenance and Reengineering
Notes: This “paper discusses how software reengineering techniques, like dynamic analysis and refactoring, can be applied to the field of energy-aware computing, to monitor, analyze, and optimize the energy profile of mobile applications and devices” (Jelschen et al., 2012, p. 347)

Title: Exploring the energy consumption of data sorting algorithms in embedded and mobile environments
Authors: Bunse, Christian; Höpfner, Hagen; Mansour, Essam; Roychoudhury, Suman
Venue: 2009 Tenth International Conference on Mobile Data Management: Systems, Services and Middleware
Notes: Paper finds that sorting algorithms that use in place sorting are more energy efficient than those that do not. They also find that data structures influence the energy consumption of the sorting algorithms

Title: Making web applications more energy efficient for OLED smartphones
Authors: Li, Ding; Tran, Angelica Huyen; Halfond, William GJ
Venue: Proceedings of the 36th International Conference on Software Engineering
Notes: Paper proposes to “automatically rewriting web applications so that they generate more energy efficient web pages.” (Li et al., 2014, p. 527) Achieving “a 40% reduction in display power consumption.” (Li et al., 2014, p. 527)

Title: What is keeping my phone awake? Characterizing and detecting no-sleep energy bugs in smartphone apps
Authors: Pathak, Abhinav; Jindal, Abhilash; Hu, Y. Charlie; Midkiff, Samuel P.
Venue: Proceedings of the 10th international conference on Mobile systems, applications, and services
Notes: Paper proposes refactorings and analysis of the no-sleep bugs for mobile devices.

Title: Energy optimization in Android applications through wakelock placement
Authors: Alam, Faisal; Panda, Preeti Ranjan; Tripathi, Nikhil; Sharma, Namita; Narayan, Sanjiv
Venue: 2014 Design, Automation & Test in Europe Conference & Exhibition (DATE)
Notes: Paper proposes the use of wakelocks to manage a mobile phone’s energy from an application’s code.

Title: Calculating source line level energy information for android applications
Authors: Li, Ding; Hao, Shuai; Halfond, William GJ; Govindan, Ramesh
Venue: Proceedings of the 2013 International Symposium on Software Testing and Analysis
Notes: Paper “presented our approach for calculating the source line level energy consumption of Android applications.” (Li et al., 2013, p. 87)

Title: An empirical study of the energy consumption of android applications
Authors: Li, Ding; Hao, Shuai; Gui, Jiaping; Halfond, William GJ
Venue: 2014 IEEE International Conference on Software Maintenance and Evolution
Notes: Paper provides “developers with objective information about how energy is consumed by a broad sample of mobile applications and can guide them in their efforts of improving the energy efficiency of their applications. Keywords—Mobile” (Li et al., 2014, p. 121)

Title: Managing the energy-delay tradeoff in mobile applications with tempus
Authors: Nikzad, Nima; Radi, Marjan; Chipara, Octav; Griswold, William G.
Venue: Proceedings of the 16th Annual Middleware Conference
Notes: Paper proposes Tempus, a framework that “saves power by enabling programmers to annotate power-hungry operations with states that specify when the operation can be executed to save energy.” (Nikzad et al., 2015, p. 259)

Title: An investigation into energy-saving programming practices for android smartphone app development
Authors: Li, Ding; Halfond, William GJ
Venue: Proceedings of the 3rd International Workshop on Green and Sustainable Software
Notes: Paper “conducted a small-scale empirical evaluation of commonly suggested energy-saving and performance-enhancing coding practices.” (Li and Halfond, 2014, p. 46)

Title: Android app energy efficiency: The impact of language, runtime, compiler, and implementation
Authors: Chen, Xinbo; Zong, Ziliang
Venue: 2016 IEEE international conferences on big data and cloud computing (BDCloud), social computing and networking (socialcom), sustainable computing and communications (sustaincom)(BDCloud/SocialCom/SustainCom)
Notes: “Paper makes contributions towards answering the question most Android app developers are facing: How to reduce the energy consumption of my app?” (Chen and Zong, 2016, p. 492)

Title: Automated energy optimization of http requests for mobile applications
Authors: Li, Ding; Lyu, Yingjun; Gui, Jiaping; Halfond, William GJ
Venue: 2016 IEEE/ACM 38th International Conference on Software Engineering (ICSE)
Notes: Paper proposes to use static analysis of code to bundle the code’s HTTP requests in order to save energy.

Title: Self-adaptive battery and context aware mobile application development
Authors: Datta, Soumya Kanti; Bonnet, Christian; Nikaein, Navid
Venue: 2014 International Wireless Communications and Mobile Computing Conference (IWCMC)
Notes: Paper proposes for application developers to use a mobile device’s energy modes in their applications to increase energy efficiency.

Title: Optimization in power usage of smartphones
Authors: Naik, Balaji A.; Chavan, R. K.
Venue: International Journal of Computer Applications
Notes: Paper proposes several techniques at the application level to improve energy efficiency.

Title: Green: A framework for supporting energy-conscious programming using controlled approximation
Authors: Baek, Woongki; Chilimbi, Trishul M.
Venue: Proceedings of the 31st ACM SIGPLAN Conference on Programming Language Design and Implementation
Notes: Paper proposes a framework that allows programmers to take advantage of approximation opportunities in a systematic manner while providing statistical QoS guarantees.

Title: Green software requirements and measurement: random decision forests-based software energy consumption profiling
Authors: Beghoura, Mohamed Amine; Boubetra, Abdelhak; Boukerram, Abdallah
Venue: Requirements Engineering
Notes: Paper proposed a machine learning based energy profiling tool that provided relevant information on the energy consumption of software applications.

Title: Software-based energy profiling of android apps: Simple, efficient and reliable?
Authors: Di Nucci, Dario; Palomba, Fabio; Prota, Antonio; Panichella, Annibale; Zaidman, Andy; De Lucia, Andrea
Venue: 2017 IEEE 24th international conference on software analysis, evolution and reengineering (SANER)
Notes: Paper “proposes PETRA, a new Android-specific tool for estimating the energy consumption of mobile applications.” (Di Nucci et al., 2017, p. 11)

Title: Seflab: A lab for measuring software energy footprints
Authors: Ferreira, Miguel A.; Hoekstra, Eric; Merkus, Bo; Visser, Bram; Visser, Joost
Venue: 2013 2nd International workshop on green and sustainable software (GREENS)
Notes: Paper proposes the “SEFLab setup, which caters for comparing applications on energy dissipation.” (Ferreira et al., 2013, p. 9)

Title: A source-level energy optimization framework for mobile applications
Authors: Li, Xueliang; Gallagher, John P.
Venue: 2016 IEEE 16th International Working Conference on Source Code Analysis and Manipulation (SCAM)
Notes: Paper “propose an energy optimization framework guided by a source code energy model that allows developers to be aware of energy usage induced by the code and to apply very targeted source-level refactoring strategies.” (Li and Gallagher, 2016, p. 1)

Title: Investigating Energy and Security Trade-offs in the Classroom with the Atom ${$LEAP$}$ Testbed
Authors: Peterson, Peter AH; Singh, Digvijay; Kaiser, William J.; Reiher, Peter L.
Venue: 4th Workshop on Cyber Security Experimentation and Test (CSET 11)
Notes: Paper tests the Atom Leap in a classroom setting to measure its accuracy and usability. This measuring framework allows us “to measure small code segments in the kernel or in user space.” (Peterson et al., 2011, p. 1)

Title: A comprehensive study on the energy efficiency of java’s thread-safe collections
Authors: Pinto, Gustavo; Liu, Kenan; Castor, Fernando; Liu, Yu David
Venue: 2016 IEEE International Conference on Software Maintenance and Evolution (ICSME)
Notes: Paper examines Java’s thread safe data structures and proposes to use data structures that increase energy efficiency.

Title: EnerJ: Approximate data types for safe and general low-power computation
Authors: Sampson, Adrian; Dietl, Werner; Fortuna, Emily; Gnanapragasam, Danushen; Ceze, Luis; Grossman, Dan
Venue: ACM SIGPLAN Notices
Notes: Paper proposes to use approximate data types that declare data that may be subject to approximate computation in order to improve energy efficiency.

Title: Exploiting significance of computations for energy-constrained approximate computing
Authors: Vassiliadis, Vassilis; Chalios, Charalampos; Parasyris, Konstantinos; Antonopoulos, Christos D.; Lalis, Spyros; Bellas, Nikolaos; Vandierendonck, Hans; Nikolopoulos, Dimitrios S.
Venue: International Journal of Parallel Programming
Notes: Paper proposes a “simple programming model allows developers to structure the computation in different tasks, and to express the relative importance of these tasks for the quality of the end result.” (Vassiliadis et al., 2016, p. 1078)

Title: Towards automatic significance analysis for approximate computing
Authors: Vassiliadis, Vassilis; Riehme, Jan; Deussen, Jens; Parasyris, Konstantinos; Antonopoulos, Christos D.; Bellas, Nikolaos; Lalis, Spyros; Naumann, Uwe
Venue: 2016 IEEE/ACM International Symposium on Code Generation and Optimization (CGO)
Notes: Paper proposes a framework “that produces a mathematically rigorous approach to automate specification of computational significance.” (Vassiliadis et al., 2016, p. 192) A programmer can then use “ this analysis to partition an application into OpenMP-like tasks and to rank these tasks according to their contribution to the output result.” (Vassiliadis et al., 2016, p. 192)

Title: Greenoracle: Estimating software energy consumption with energy measurement corpora
Authors: Chowdhury, Shaiful Alam; Hindle, Abram
Venue: 2016 IEEE/ACM 13th Working Conference on Mining Software Repositories (MSR)
Notes: Paper proposes an“approach whereby a collection of prior applications’ energy measurements allows us to train, transmit, and apply the model to estimate any foreign application’s energy consumption for a test run.” (Chowdhury and Hindle, 2016, p. 49)

Title: Process-level power estimation in vm-based systems
Authors: Colmant, Maxime; Kurpicz, Mascha; Felber, Pascal; Huertas, Loïc; Rouvoy, Romain; Sobe, Anita
Venue: Proceedings of the Tenth European Conference on Computer Systems
Notes: Paper proposes “BITWATTS which crosses the boundaries of virtual environments and provide an estimation of the power consumption of applications running within virtual machines (VMs).” (Colmant et al., 2015, p. 13)

Title: Leafactor: Improving energy efficiency of android apps via automatic refactoring
Authors: Cruz, Luis; Abreu, Rui; Rouvignac, Jean-Noël
Venue: 2017 IEEE/ACM 4th International Conference on Mobile Software Engineering and Systems (MOBILESoft)
Notes: Paper proposes “Leafactor is a tool to automatically improve the energy consumption of Android apps.” (Cruz et al., 2017, p. 1)

Title: Haskell in green land: Analyzing the energy behavior of a purely functional language
Authors: Lima, Luís Gabriel; Soares-Neto, Francisco; Lieuthier, Paulo; Castor, Fernando; Melfe, Gilberto; Fernandes, João Paulo
Venue: 2016 IEEE 23rd international conference on Software Analysis, Evolution, and Reengineering (SANER)
Notes: Paper proposes to extend multiple Haskell profilers to help developers measure energy consumption.

Title: Energy types
Authors: Cohen, Michael; Zhu, Haitao Steve; Senem, Emgin Ezgi; Liu, Yu David
Venue: Proceedings of the ACM international conference on Object oriented programming systems languages and applications
Notes: Paper describes a programming model where energy phases and modes can be intuitively specified by programmers to increase the energy consumption of applications

Title: Predicting data structures for energy efficient computing
Authors: Michanan, Junya; Dewri, Rinku; Rutherford, Matthew J.
Venue: 2015 Sixth International Green and Sustainable Computing Conference (IGSC)
Notes: Paper proposes a “detailed a concept and an architecture for building adaptive green data structures that can intelligently adapt for energy efficiency.” (Michanan et al., 2015, p. 8)

Title: Energy efficient data sorting using standard sorting algorithms
Authors: Bunse, Christian; Höpfner, Hagen; Roychoudhury, Suman; Mansour, Essam
Venue: International Conference on Software and Data Technologies
Notes: Paper has already been included.

Title: SPELLing out energy leaks: Aiding developers locate energy inefficient code
Authors: Pereira, Rui; Carção, Tiago; Couto, Marco; Cunha, Jácome; Fernandes, João Paulo; Saraiva, João
Venue: Journal of Systems and Software
Notes: Paper “proposes a technique to detect energy inefficient fragments in the source code of a software system.” (Pereira et al., 2020, p. 1)

Title: Energy profiles of java collections classes
Authors: Hasan, Samir; King, Zachary; Hafiz, Munawar; Sayagh, Mohammed; Adams, Bram; Hindle, Abram
Venue: Proceedings of the 38th International Conference on Software Engineering
Notes: Paper analyzes an applications code to “to selectively replace Collections types used in six applications and libraries.” (Hasan et al., 2016, p. 225)

Title: Automated Refactoring for Energy-Aware Software
Authors: Bree, Déaglán Connolly; Cinnéide, Mel Ó
Venue: 2021 IEEE International Conference on Software Maintenance and Evolution (ICSME)
Notes: Paper describes two possible ways of refactoring an application for energy code smells.

Title: Removing Decorator to Improve Energy Efficiency
Authors: Bree, Déaglán Connolly; Cinnéide, Mel Ó
Venue: 2022 IEEE International Conference on Software Analysis, Evolution and Reengineering (SANER)
Notes: Paper proposes to eliminate the decorator pattern to increase the energy efficiency of applications.

Title: Comparing the Energy Consumption of Java I/O Libraries and Methods
Authors: Ournani, Zakaria; Rouvoy, Romain; Rust, Pierre; Penhoat, Joel
Venue: 37th International Conference on Software Maintenance and Evolution (ICSME)
Notes: Paper analyzes different io libraries in the Java language and proposes to substitute libraries to increase the energy efficiency of an application.

Title: Evaluating the Impact of Java Virtual Machines on Energy Consumption
Authors: Ournani, Zakaria; Belgaid, Mohammed Chakib; Rouvoy, Romain; Rust, Pierre; Penhoat, Joel
Venue: Proceedings of the 15th ACM/IEEE International Symposium on Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement (ESEM)
Notes: Paper proposes “an Open source tool, named JReferral that recommends an energy-efficient JVM distribution and configuration for any Java application.” (Ournani et al., 2021, p. 1)

Title: Comparing REST, SOAP, Socket and gRPC in computation offloading of mobile applications: An energy cost analysis
Authors: Chamas, Carolina Luiza; Cordeiro, Daniel; Eler, Marcelo Medeiros
Venue: 2017 IEEE 9th Latin-American Conference on Communications (LATINCOM)
Notes: Paper investigates which communication protocol is most energy efficient, REST, SOAP, Socket, or gRPC.

Title: Energy saving strategies in the design of mobile device applications
Authors: Meneses-Viveros, Amilcar; Hernández-Rubio, Erika; Mendoza, Sonia; Rodríguez, José; Quintos, Ana Belem Márquez
Venue: Sustainable Computing: Informatics and Systems
Notes: Paper reviews several energy saving techniques from a developers perspective.

Title: Enforcing green code with Android lint
Authors: Goaër, Olivier Le
Venue: Proceedings of the 35th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering Workshops
Notes: Paper proposes to extend the Android Studio IDE to add a power consumption tests.

Title: Architectural Tactics to Optimize Software for Energy Efficiency in the Public Cloud
Authors: Vos, Sophie; Lago, Patricia; Verdecchia, Roberto; Heitlager, Ilja
Venue: International Conference on ICT for Sustainability
Notes: Paper proposes energy tactics that can be used by developers using the public cloud.

Title: EARLY ANALYSIS OF SOFTWARE ARCHITECTURE TO ESTIMATE ENERGY CONSUMPTION IN ANDROID PLATFORM
Authors: AL NIDAWI, HASAN SAJID ATTA; WEI, KOH TIENG; KHALEEL, AMMAR; DAWOOD, KAREEM ABBAS
Venue: Journal of Theoretical and Applied Information Technology
Notes: Paper presents “the evaluation of two architectures (i.e. server-centric and mobilecentric architectures) and analysed how their battery consumption depends on the software architecture used to run the application.” (AL NIDAWI et al., 2018, p. 7861) They find that mobile-centric applications are more energy efficient than server-centric applications when it comes to data retrieval.

Title: GREEN MOBILE APPLICATION DEVELOPMENT THROUGH SOFTWARE LOCALIZATION
Authors: Kasakliev, Nikolay; Somova, Elena; Gocheva, Margarita
Venue: International Journal on Information Technologies & Security
Notes: Paper proposes for application developers to use different types of localization depending on their application’s needs in order to save energy.

Title: Automated re-factoring of android apps to enhance energy-efficiency
Authors: Banerjee, Abhijeet; Roychoudhury, Abhik
Venue: Proceedings of the International Conference on Mobile Software Engineering and Systems
Notes: Paper presents “a light-weight re-factoring technique that can assist in energyaware app development.” (Banerjee and Roychoudhury, 2016, p. 139)

Title: Melta: A method level energy estimation technique for android development
Authors: Farooq, Muhammad Umer; Khan, Saif Ur Rehman; Beg, Mirza Omer
Venue: 2019 International Conference on Innovative Computing (ICIC)
Notes: Paper proposes “a probabilistic technique for fine-grained energy estimation to compute the energy consumption of each method in Android applications.” (Farooq et al., 2019, p. 1)

Title: Green configurations of functional quality attributes
Authors: Horcas, Jose-Miguel; Pinto, Mónica; Fuentes, Lidia
Venue: Proceedings of the 21st International Systems and Software Product Line Conference-Volume A
Notes: Paper “proposes a solution to help the software architect to generate congurations of functional quality attributes whilst keeping the energy consumed by the application as low as possible.” (Horcas et al., 2017, p. 79)

Title: Software energy measurement at different levels of granularity
Authors: Ghaleb, Taher Ahmed
Venue: 2019 International Conference on Computer and Information Sciences (ICCIS)
Notes: Paper reviews different software measurement tools.

Title: Self-adaptive energy-efficent applications: the hadas developing approach
Authors: Horcas, Jose Miguel; Pinto, Mónica; Fuentes, Lidia; Gámez, Nadia
Venue: 2017 IEEE 15th Intl Conf on Dependable, Autonomic and Secure Computing, 15th Intl Conf on Pervasive Intelligence and Computing, 3rd Intl Conf on Big Data Intelligence and Computing and Cyber Science and Technology Congress (DASC/PiCom/DataCom/CyberSciTech)
Notes: Paper proposes “the HADAS green assistant, which helps developers to identify the energy-consuming concerns of their applications (i.e., points in the application that consume more energy, like storing or transferring data), and also to model, analyse and reason about different architectural solutions for each of these concerns.” (Gamez et al., 2016, p. 1)

Title: Estimating software energy consumption with machine learning approach by software performance feature
Authors: Fu, Cuijiao; Qian, Depei; Luan, Zhongzhi
Venue: 2018 IEEE International Conference on Internet of Things (iThings) and IEEE Green Computing and Communications (GreenCom) and IEEE Cyber, Physical and Social Computing (CPSCom) and IEEE Smart Data (SmartData)
Notes: Paper presents “a method for classifying software based on performance features.” (Fu et al., 2018, p. 490)

Title: Variability models for generating efficient configurations of functional quality attributes
Authors: Horcas, Jose-Miguel; Pinto, Mónica; Fuentes, Lidia
Venue: Information and Software Technology
Notes: Paper “presents a process that helps developers to automatically generate optimum configurations of functional quality attributes in terms of energy efficiency and performance.” (Horcas et al., 2018, p. 147)
